Uses of Interface
javaslang.concurrent.Future

  • Packages that use Future 
    Package Description
    javaslang.concurrent
    This package contains basic building blocks creating fast, asynchronous, non-blocking parallel code.

    • Uses of Future in javaslang.concurrent

      Methods in javaslang.concurrent that return Future 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      default Future<T> Future.andThen(Consumer<? super Try<T>> action)
      Support for chaining of callbacks that are guaranteed to be executed in a specific order.
      default Future<Throwable> Future.failed()
      A projection that inverses the result of this Future.
      static <T> Future<T> Future.failed(ExecutorService executorService, Throwable exception)
      Creates a failed Future with the given exception, backed by the given ExecutorService.
      static <T> Future<T> Future.failed(Throwable exception)
      Creates a failed Future with the given exception, backed by the DEFAULT_EXECUTOR_SERVICE.
      default Future<T> Future.fallbackTo(Future<? extends T> that)
      Returns a Future that returns the result of this Future, if it is a success.

      default Future<T> Future.filterNot(Predicate<? super T> predicate) 
      static <T> Future<Option<T>> Future.find(ExecutorService executorService, Iterable<? extends Future<? extends T>> futures, Predicate<? super T> predicate)
      Returns a Future that eventually succeeds with the first result of the given Futures which matches the given predicate.

      Maps the values of an iterable in parallel to a sequence of mapped values into a single Future by transforming an Iterable<? extends T> into a Future<Seq<U>>.

      Maps the values of an iterable in parallel to a sequence of mapped values into a single Future by transforming an Iterable<? extends T> into a Future<Seq<U>>.
      default <U> Future<Tuple2<T,U>> Future.zip(Future<? extends U> that)
      Returns a tuple of this and that Future result.
